title-group.article-title: Dispersion of horizontally polarized shear waves in an irregular non-homogeneous self-reinforced crustal layer over a semi-infinite self-reinforced medium

article-meta.aff: Department of Applied Mathematics, Indian School of Mines, Dhanbad, Jharkhand, India

author-notes.corresp: Amares Chattopadhyay, Department of Applied Mathematics, Indian School of Mines, Dhanbad, 826 004, Jharkhand, India Email: c_amares@yahoo.com

permissions.copyright-statement: © The Author(s) 2012 Reprints and permissions: sagepub.co.uk/journalsPermissions.nav

abstract.p: The present paper discusses the dispersion equation for horizontally polarized shear waves (SH waves) in a non-homogeneous self-reinforced layer over a semi infinite self-reinforced medium with an irregularity. The dispersion equation has been obtained in closed form. In the isotropic case, when non homogeneity and irregularity are absent, the dispersion equation reduces to standard SH wave equation. The dispersion curves have been presented by means of graphs for different sizes of irregularity and different values of non-homogeneity parameters. The influence of depth of irregularity and non-homogeneity parameters on phase velocity has been studied.

sec.title: 1. Introduction
sec.p: The studies of propagation of horizontally polarized shear waves (SH waves) in an anisotropic medium are of great importance, as they help to investigate the structure of earth. Particularly, the study of wave propagation in a self-reinforced media plays a vital role in the construction sector and in geophysics. Self-reinforced materials are a family of composite materials such as alumina or concrete. The characteristic property of such materials is that their components act together as a single anisotropic unit up to their elastic condition. Theoretical and experimental studies regarding to better understanding of the real earth has led to a need for more realistic representation of the medium through which seismic waves propagate.

Belfield et al. (1983) delivered the idea of introducing continuous self-reinforcement at every point of an elastic solid. Later on Verma and Rana (1983) applied this model to the rotation of a tube, illustrating its utilityin strengthening the lateral surface of the tube. Propagation of the SH wave in a self-reinforced medium has been studied before by many authors. Verma (1986) studied the propagation of magnetoelastic SH waves in self-reinforced bodies. Chattopadhyay and Chaudhury (1990) studied the propagation, reflection and transmission of a magnetoelastic SH wave in a self-reinforced elastic medium. Propagation of magnetoelastic SH waves in an infinite self-reinforced plate has also been discussed by Chattopadhyay and Chaudhury (1995).

Propagation of waves has been studied by many authors who assumed different forms of irregularities at the interface. Bhattacharya (1962) discussed the dispersion curves for Love wave propagation in a transversely isotropic crustal layer with an irregularity in the interface. Chattopadhyay et al. (1983) studied the propagation of an SH guided wave in an internal stratum with parabolic irregularity in the lower interface. Wave propagation in crystalline media plays a very interesting role in geophysics as well as in ultrasonic and signal processing. Keeping in the mind the fact that the non-homogeneity characteristic is one of the most generalized elastic conditions inside the earth, many authors have studied the propagation of different waves in different media with non-homogeneity. Chattopadhyay and Bandyopadhyay (1986) have studied the propagation of SH waves in an infinite monoclinic crystal plate as well as in infinite anisotropic non-homogeneous monoclinic plate. Chattopadhyay (1975) studied the Love wave propagation due to irregularity in the thickness of non-homogeneous crustal layer. Propagation of Love waves in a non-homogeneous stratum of finite depth sandwiched between two semi infinite isotropic media has been studied earlier by Sinha (1967). Recently, the propagation of SH waves in an irregular monoclinic crustal layer has been studied by Chattopadhyay et al. (2008).

This paper is concerned with the propagation of SH waves in a non-homogeneous self-reinforced crustal layer overlying a semi-infinite self-reinforced medium with an irregularity. The irregularity is in the form of a rectangle. The perturbation technique indicated by Erigen and Samuels (1959) has been used. The dispersion curves have been depicted by means of graphs fordifferent size of irregularity and different values of non-homogeneity parameters. Influence of the depth of irregularity and non-homogeneity parameters on phase velocity has been studied.

sec.title: 2. Formulation of the problem
sec.p:
The x-axis has been taken along the interface (betweenthe lower semi infinite medium and the non-homogeneous self-reinforced layer) and z-axis is taken positive downwards (Figure 1). The irregularity has been taken in rectangular form with length s and depth H'. Thickness of the layer is H and origin is placed at the middle point of the interface. The source of disturbance S is situated at distance d, where d>H'. Figure 1.
Geometry of the problem.
The interface between layer and half space is defined as (1)z=ɛh(x) where h(x)={0forx≤-s2,x≥s2f(x)for-s2≤x≤s2 where ɛ=H's and ɛ<<1.

The constitutive equation for a self-reinforced linearly elastic model, used by Belfield et al. (1983), is as follows (2)τij=λekkδij+2μTeij+α(akamekmδij+ekkaiaj)+2(μL-μT)(aiakekj+ajakeki)+βakamekmaiaj, i,j,k,m = 1,2,3 where τij are components of stress, eij components of infinitesimal strain, δij Kronecker delta, ai components of a, all referred to rectangular Cartesian co-ordinates xi. a=(a1,a2,a3) is the preferred directions of reinforcement such that a12+a22+a32=1. The vector a may be function of position. Indices take the values 1, 2, 3 and summation convention is employed. The coefficients λ,μL,μT,α and β are elastic constants with dimension of stress. μT can be identified as the shear modulus in transverse shear across the preferred direction, and μLas the shear modulus in longitudinal shear in the preferred direction. α and β are specific stress components to take into account different layers for concrete part of the composite material.
Equations governing the propagation of small elastic disturbances in the absence of body forces are (3)τij,j=ρ∂2ui∂t2
let ui=(u1,v1,w1) and denoting x1=x,x2=y,x3=z, then equation (3) can be written as (4)g.∂τ11∂x+∂τ12∂y+∂τ13∂z=ρ∂2u1∂t2∂τ12∂x+∂τ22∂y+∂τ23∂z=ρ∂2v1∂t2∂τ13∂x+∂τ23∂y+∂τ33∂z=ρ∂2w1∂t2.
For SH wave propagating in the x- direction and causing displacement in the y- direction only, it follows, (5)u1=w1=0,v1=v1(x,z,t)and∂∂y≡0
For non-homogeneous self-reinforced layer, the non homogeneity has been considered as (6)μL1=μL'eνz,μT1=μT'eνzandρ1=ρ1'eνz.
Using equations (2), (5) and (6) in equation (4) the equation of motion for self-reinforced layer is obtained

as (7)P'∂2v1∂z2+R'∂2v1∂z∂x+Q'∂2v1∂x2+νR2'∂v1∂x +νP'∂v1∂z=ρ1'∂2v1∂t2 where, P'=μT'+a32(μL'-μT')Q'=μT'+a12(μL'-μT')andR'=2a1a3(μL'-μT')} and equation of motion for lower self-reinforced semi-infinite medium, as (8)P''∂2v2∂z2+R''∂2v2∂z∂x+Q''∂2v2∂x2=ρ2∂2v2∂t2 where, P″=μT''+a32(μL''-μT'')Q″=μT''+a12(μL''-μT'')andR″=2a1a3(μL''-μT'')}
Here in equations (7) and (8) suffix “1” and “2” are used for self-reinforced layer and lower semi-infinite medium respectively.
The boundary conditions are as follows:
(i) The upper surface of self-reinforced layer is stress free (9)R'2∂v1∂x+P'∂v1∂z=0 atz=-H
(ii) The stresses are continuous at the interface y=ɛh(z)(10)∂v1∂z[P'-R'2ɛh']eνɛh+∂v1∂x[R'2-Q'ɛh']eνɛh =[P''-R''2ɛh']∂v2∂z+[R''2-Q''ɛh']∂v2∂x
where h'=dh(x)dx
(iii) The displacements are continuous at the interface z=ɛh(x)(11)v1=v2

sec.title: 3. Solution of the problem
sec.p: Let vi(z,x,t)=Vi(z,x)eiωt(i=1,2…) be considered, then the equations (7) and (8) reduces to (12)P'∂2V1∂z2+R'∂2V1∂z∂x+Q'∂2V1∂x2+νR'2∂V1∂x +νP'∂V1∂z+ρ1'ω2V1=0 and (13)P''∂2V2∂y2+R''∂2V2∂y∂z+Q''∂2V2∂z2+ρ2ω2V2=0 where ω is circular frequency.
Defining the Fourier transform V¯r(z,η) of Vr(z,x)(r=1,2) as V¯r(z,η)=∫-∞∞Vr(z,x)eiηxdx the inverse Fourier transform is found as Vr(z,x)=12π∫-∞∞V¯r(z,η)e-iηxdη.

Therefore, the Fourier transform of equations (12) and (13) are (14)d2V¯1dz2+(ν+b1)dV¯1dz+(p12+b1ν2)V¯1=0 and (15)d2V¯2dz2+b2dV¯2dz-(p22)V¯2=0 where, β12=μT'ρ1',β22=μT″ρ2,b1=-iηR'P',b2=-iηR″P″p12=ω2β12{1+a32(μL'μT'-1)}-Q'P'η2p22=Q″P″η2-ω2β22{1+a32(μL''μT''-1)}

Now the solutions of equations (14) and (15) are (16)V¯1=e-(ν+b12)z(Acosp3z+Bsinp3z) and (17)V¯2=De-(b22)ze-p4z where, p32=p12-(ν2+b124)={ω2β12{1+a32(μL'μT'-1)}-Q'P'η2+(R'2P')2η2-ν24} p42=p22+b224={Q''P''η2-ω2β22{1+a32(μL''μT''-1)}-(R''2P'')2η2}andA,B,Dare functions ofη.
The displacements in the two media are as follows: (18)V1=12π∫-∞∞e-g(ν+b12g)zg(Acosp3z+Bsinp3zg)e-iηxdη and (19)V2=12π∫-∞∞{De-(b22)ze-p4z+2p4+a22e(p4+b22)ze-(p4+b22)d}e-iηxdη
where the second term in the integrand of V2 is introduced due to the effect of source at S in lower semi-infinite medium.
Now the following approximations are set due to small value of ɛ(20)A≅A0+A1ɛ,B≅B0+B1ɛ,D≅D0+D1ɛ

Since the boundary is not uniform at the interface of M1 and M2 so the terms A,BandD appearing in equation (20) are also functions of ɛ. Expanding these terms in ascending powers of ɛ and keeping in view that ɛ is small and so retaining the terms up to the first order of ɛ.
These assumptions are justified in the real earth model where the depth H'of the irregular boundary is too small with respect to the length of the boundary s. Also for small ɛ,
following approximations can be accepted e±γɛh≅1±γɛh,cosp3ɛh≅1,sinp3ɛh≅p3ɛh where γ is any quantity.

The boundary condition (i) gives (21)R'2{(A0+A1ɛ)cosp3H-(B0+B1ɛ)sinp3H}(-iη)+P' [(A0+A1ɛ){p3sinp3H-(ν+b12)cosp3H} +(B0+B1ɛ){p3cosp3H+(ν+b12)sinp3H}=0 and the boundary condition (iii) follows (22)ɛ∫-∞∞{ν+b12A0-p3B0-(p4+b22)D0+2e-(p4+b22)d} h(x)e-iηxdη=∫-∞∞{(A0-D0-2e-(p4+a22)d(p4+a22)) +ɛ(A1-D1)}e-iηxdη
Now taking the Fourier transform of h(x)defined as (23)h¯(λ)=∫-∞∞h(x)eiλxdx so that, (24)h(x)=12π∫-∞∞h¯(λ)e-iλxdλ (25)andh'(x)=-i2π∫-∞∞λh¯(λ)e-iλxdλ

Now applying the transform (24) and (25) on equation (22), the following is obtained (26)ɛ2π∫-∞∞[∫-∞∞((ν+b12)A0-p3B0 -(p4+b22)D0+2e-(p4+b22)d)h¯(λ)e-i(η+λ)xdη]dλ =∫-∞∞{(A0-D0-2e-(p4+b22)d(p4+b22))+ɛ(A1-D1)}e-iηxdη

Taking η+λ=k for the inner integral in the left-hand side of the equation (26), so that λ may be treated as a constant such that dη=dk. Replacing η by k in theright-hand side of the equation (26) and finally after taking Fourier transform as defined above, it follows (27)A0-D0-2e-(p4+b22)d(p4+b22)+ɛ(A1-D1)=ɛR1(k) where, (28)R1(k)=12π∫-∞∞[(ν+b12)A0-p3B0-(p4+b22)D0 +2e-(p4+b22)d]η=k-λh¯(λ)dλ

Now the boundary condition (ii) gives (29)eνɛhg(P'-R'2ɛh'g)12π∫-∞∞g[-g(ν+b12g)e-g(ν+b12g)zg. g.g(Acosp3z+Bsinp3zg)+e-g(ν+b12g)zg(-Asinp3zg gg+Bcosp3zg)p3e-iηxdηg]+eνɛhg(R'2-Q'ɛh'g) ×12π∫-∞∞e-g(ν+b12g)zg(Acosp3z+Bsinp3zg)g(-iηg)e-iηxdη =g(P″-R″2ɛh'g)12π∫-∞∞g[Dg(p4+b22g)g.e-g(p4+b22g)dg g+2eg(p4+b22g)ze-g(p4+b22g)dg]e-iηxdη+g(R″2-Q″ɛh'g) ∫-∞∞g[Dg(p4+b22g)e-g(p4+b22g)d+2eg(p4+b22g)ze-g(p4+b22g)dg] (-iη)e-iηxdη at z=ɛh(x).

Using the equations (23), (24) and (25) in equation(29) and proceeding as in equation (27), it follows (30)P'g[g{-g(ν+b12g)A0+p3B0g}gg +ɛg{-g(ν+b12g)A1+p3B1g}g]-ikR'2g(A0+ɛA1g) -P''g[g{-g(p4+b22g)D0g.g.g.+2e-g(p4+b22g)dg}g] -ɛ(p4+b22)D1]+ikR''2{D0+2e-(p4+b22)d(p4+b22)+ɛD1} =ɛR2(k) where, (31)R2(k)=12π∫-∞∞[P''{(p4+b22)2D0 +2(p4+b22)e-(p4+b22)d}-ikR''2{-(p4+b22)D0 +2e-(p4+b22)d}-P'[{(ν+b12)A0-p3B0}(ν+b12) +p3{-p3A0-(ν+b12)B0}] -νP'{-(ν+b12)A0+p3B0} +ikR'2{-(ν+b12)A0+p3B0}+ikνA0R'2 -iλ[R''2{(p4+b22)D0-2e-(p4+b22)d} +ikQ''{D0+2e-(p4+b22)d(p4+b22)} -R'2{(ν+b12)A0-p3B0}-ikQ'A0]]η=k-λh¯(λ)dλ.

Equating the absolute terms (terms not containing ɛ) and the coefficient of ɛ from equations (21), (27) and (30), it follows (32)A0[R'2(-ik)cosp3H +P'{p3sinp3H-(ν+b12)cosp3H}] +B0[R'2(ik)sinp3H+P'{p3cosp3H +(ν+b12)sinp3H}]=0 (33)A1[R'2(-ik)cosp3H +P'{p3sinp3H-(ν+b12)cosp3H}] +B1[R'2(ik)sinp3H +P'{p3cosp3H+(ν+b12)sinp3H}]=0 (34)A0-D0-2e-(p4+b22)d(p4+b22)=0 (35)A1-D1=R1(k) (36)A0{-P'(ν+b12)-ikR'2} +B0p3P'+D0{P''(p4+b22)+ikR″2} -2P''e-(p4+b22)d+ikR″e-(p4+b22)d(p4+b22)=0(36) (37)A1{-P'(ν+b12)-ikR'2}+B1p3P'+D1{P''(p4+b22)+ikR″2}=R2(k).

Solving the above six equations the following is obtained A0=-8P''e-(p4+b22)d{ikR'tanp3H+2p3P' +(ν+b1)P'tanp3H}G(k) B0=-8P''e-(p4+b22)d{ikR'-2p3P'tanp3H+(ν+b1)C66'}G(k) D0=-4e-(p4+b22)d(2p4+b2)G(k){E1+E2+E3+E4} A1=-{R1(2p4P''+a2P''+ikR'')+2R2}{ikR'tanp3H+2p3P'+(ν+a1)P'tanp3H}G(k) B1=-{R1(2p4P''+a2P''+ikR'')+2R2}{ikR'-2p3P'tanp3H+(ν+a1)P'}G(k) D1=E5+E6G(k) E1=2ikp4P″R'tanp3H+ikb2P″R'tanp3H+4p3p4P″P'+2p3b2P″P' E2=2p4(ν+b1)P″P'tanp3H+b2(ν+b1)P″P'tanp3H-2ikp3P'R'+4p32P'2tanp3H E3=2ik(ν+b1)P'R'tanp3H+(ν+b1)2P'2tanp3H-k2R'2tanp3H+2ik(ν+b1)P'R'tanp3H E4=k2R″R'tanp3H-2ikp3R″P'-ik(ν+b1)R″P'tanp3H E5=R2(-2ikR'tanp3H-4p3P'-2(ν+b1)P'tanp3H) E6=R1(k2R'2tanp3H-4p32P'2tanp3H-2ik(ν+b1)P'R'tanp3H-(ν+b1)2P'2tanp3H) G(k)=-k2R'2tanp3H-2ikp4R'P″tanp3H+k2R″R'tanp3H4p32P'2tanp3H+2ik(ν+b1)P'R'tanp3H+(ν+b1)2P'2tanp3H-4p3p4P″P'-2ikp3R″P'-ik(ν+b1)R″P'tanp3H-2p3b2P″P'-2p4(ν+b1)P″P'tanp3H-b2(ν+b1)P″P'tanp3H-ikb2R'P″tanp3H.

With the help of above, the displacement in the self-reinforced layer is given by (38)V1=-12π∫-∞∞4P''e-g(p4+b22g)de-b12zG(k)g[1+ɛg{R2+R1g(P''g(p4+b22g)+ikR''2g)g}4P''e-g(p4+b22g)dg]×g{g(ikR'tanp3H+2p3P'ggg+g(ν+b1g)P'tanp3Hg)g.cosp3z+g.g(ikR'-2p3P'tanp3Hggg+g(ν+b1g)P'g)sinp3zg}e-ikxdk.
From equation (1), the interface for the rectangular irregularity gives (39)h¯(λ)=2sλsin(λs2).

Here the argument of ψ(k-λ) is because of η+λ=k. Following the asymptotic formula of Willis (1948), integral transform by Tranter (1966) and neglecting the terms containing 2/s and higher powers of 2/s for large s, it follows (41)∫-∞∞{ψ(k-λ)+ψ(k+λ)}1λsin(λs2)dλ ≅π22ψ(k)=πψ(k).
Hence on using equation (41) on equation (40) the following can be obtained (42)R2+R1{P''(p4+b22)+ikR''2} =2sP''ψ(k)=2P''H'ɛψ(k).

Therefore, in view of equation (42) the displacement in the self-reinforced layer is da1dτ=12πpr1r2∫02π{bp[-pcos(φ1-θ1)+2r2ζ1sin(φ1-θ1)]+pa1[(p-r1r2)cosφ1-2r2ζ1sinφ1]+qar[cos(φ1+θr-θ1)+2pr1ζ2sin(φ1+θr-θ1)]}sinφ1dφ1
Since the value of this integral depends entirely on the contribution of the poles of the integrand, so the dispersion equation for SH waves may be given by (43)G(k)[1-H'2ψ(k)e(p4+b22)d]=0.
The poles are located at the roots of above equation.

Equation (43) may be rewritten as (44)D2+D3+D4-H'2(D5+D6+D7+D8 +D9+D10)=0 where, D2=-k2R'2tanp3H-2ikp4R'P″tanp3H+k2R″R'tanp3H+4p32P'2tanp3H D3=2ik(ν+b1)P'R'tanp3H+(ν+b1)2P'2tanp3H-4p3p4P″P'-2ikp3R″P' D4=-ik(ν+b1)R″P'tanp3H-2p3b2P″P'-2p4(ν+b1)P″P'tanp3H-b2(ν+b1)P″P'tanp3H-ikb2R'P″tanp3H D5=4ikp3p4R'P″-2ik(ν+b1)p4R'P''tanp3H-2(ν+b1)2p4P'P″tanp3H-8p32p4P'P″tanp3H+8p32p4P'2tanp3H+4ikp4(ν+b1)P'R'tanp3H+2p4(ν+b1)2P'2tanp3H-2k2p4R'2tanp3H+2k2p4R'R″tanp3H-4ikp3p4P'R″-2ikp4(ν+b1)P'R″tanp3H D6=(p4+b22){-4ikp4R'P″tanp3H-2ikb2R'P″tanp3H-8p3p4P'P″-4p3b2P'P″-4p4(ν+b1)P'P″tanp3H-2b2(ν+b1)P'P″tanp3H} D7=b2k2R'2tanp3H-4b2p32P'2tanp3H+2ikb2p3R″P'-b2k2R'R″tanp3H-b2(ν+b1)2P'2tanp3H-2ikb2(ν+b1)R'P'tanp3H+ikb2(ν+b1)R″P'tanp3H D8=4p32(ν+b1)P'2tanp3H-4ikp3(ν+b1)R'P'-4p3(ν+b1)2P'2+ik(ν+b1)2R'P'tanp3H+(ν+b1)3P'2tanp3H-4ikp32R'P'tanp3H-8p33P'2 D9=2k2p3R'2+4ikp32R'P'tanp3H-k2(ν+b1)R'2tanp3H+ik(ν+b1)2R'P'tanp3H and D10=2νk2R'2tanp3H-4iνkp3R'P'-2iνk(ν+b1)R'P'tanp3H.

By assuming that the wave is propagating along the surface with c as the common wave velocity, the following can be set p3=kP3,p4=kP4,b1=kB1andb2=kB2 whereP3=g(c2β12g{1+a32g(μL'μT'-1g)g}-Q'P'-ν24k2+R'24P'2g)1/2 B1=-iR'P',P4=(Q″P″-c2β22{1+a32(μL''μT''-1)}-R24P2)1/2and B2=-iR″P″.

In the view of above setting, equation (44) gives (45)tan{(c2β12{1+a32(μL'μT'-1)}-Q'P'-ν24k2+R'24P'2)kH}=J1+iJ2 where, J1=L1L3+L2L4L32+L42,J2=L2L3-L1L4L32+L42 and L1=8H'k3P3P42P'P''-8k2P3P4P'P''-4H'P3P'R''+2H'k3P3P'P''R2 +8H'k3P33P'2+2H'kν2P3P'2L2=-4H'k3P3P4R'P''-4H'k3P3P4P'R''-4H'νk2P3R'P' L3=4kνP4P'P''-8k2P32P'2-2ν2P'2-2H'kν2P4P'P''-8H'k3P4P32P'P''+8H'k3P4P32P'2+2H'kν2P4P'2-4H'νk2P42P'P''+H'νk2P'R2P''-H'νk2R2P'P''-ν3H'P'2-4H'νk2P32P'2+2H'νk2R'2L4=2H'νk2P4R'P''+2H'νk2P4P'R''-4H'k3P32P'2R''P''-H'ν2kP'2R''P''-4H'k3P32R'P'-H'ν2kR'P'.
The real part of the equation (45) gives the dispersion equation of SH waves.
So, the dispersion relation for SH waves in irregular, non-homogeneous, self-reinforced layer is (46)tan{(c2β12{1+a32(μL'μT'-1)}-Q'P'-ν24k2+R'24P'2)kH}. =J1

sec.title: 4.1. Case 1
sec.p: When ν=0,andμL''=μT'' the dispersion relation (46) reduces to tan{(c2β12{1+a32(μL'μT'-1)}-Q'P'-ν24k2+R'24P'2)kH} =J3J4 where, J3=2P5(4H'kP62P'μT''-4P6P'μT''+4H'kP52P'2)(8H'kP6P52P'2-8P52P'2-8H'kP6P52P'μT'')+16H2k2P53P6R'2P'μT''J4=(8H'kP6P52P'2-8P52P'2-8H'kP6P52P'μT'')2+16H2k2P54R'2P'2P5=c2β12{1+a32(μL'μT'-1)}-Q'P'+R'24P'2P6=1-c2β22 which is the result for SH waves propagating in an irregular self-reinforced layer lying over an isotropic half space.

sec.title: 4.2. Case 2
sec.p: When ν=0,H'=0,μL''=μT'' the dispersion relation (46) reduces to tan{(c2β12{1+a32(μL'μT'-1)}-Q'P'-ν24k2+R'24P'2)kH} =μT''1-c2β22P'c2β12{1+a32(μL'μT'-1)}-Q'P'+R'24P'2 which is the result for SH waves propagating in a regular self-reinforced layer lying over an isotropic half space.

sec.title: 4.3. Case 3
sec.p: When ν=0,μL'=μT' andμL''=μT'' the dispersion relation (46) reduces to tan{(c2β12-1)kH}=J5J6 where, J5=2P7(4H'kP82μT'μT''-4P8μT'μT''+4H'kP72μT'2)(8H'kP8P72μT'2-8P72μT'2-8H'kP8P72μT'μT'')J4=(8H'kP8P72μT'2-8P72μT'2-8H'kP8P72μT'μT'')2P7=c2β12-1,P8=1-c2β22 which is the result for SH waves propagating in an irregular isotropic layer lying over an isotropic half space.

sec.title: 4.4. Case 4
sec.p: When ν=0,H'=0,μL'=μT'andμL''=μT'' the dispersion relation (46) reduces to tan{(c2β12-1)kH}=μT''1-c2β22μT'c2β12-1 which is the classical SH wave equation.

sec.title: 5. Numerical examples
sec.p:
For the case of an irregular non-homogeneous self-reinforced layer lying over self-reinforced half space, the following data are used:
For self-reinforced layer, (Markham, 1970)
μL'=5.66×109N/m2,μT'=2.46×109N/m2,ρ1'=7,800Kg/m3
For self-reinforced half space, (Gubbins, 1990)
μL''=7.07×109N/m2,μT''=3.5×109N/m2,ρ2=1,600Kg/m3
Moreover the following data are used (Hool and Kinne, 1924) a1=0,0.00316227.

The effect of non-homogeneity and irregularity on the propagation of plane SH waves; propagating in non-homogeneous self-reinforced layer with rectangular irregularity lying over a self-reinforced half space has been depicted by means of graphs, which are shown in Figures 2 to 7. These graphs give the variation of non-dimensional phase velocity (c/β1) with respect to non-dimensional wave number kH for different values of the non-homogeneity parameter (νH)and different size of irregularity. It is observed that as the size of irregularity (H'/H) increases, the phase velocity decreases. Also, the presence of non-homogeneity increases the phase velocity for the corresponding wave number. In Figures 2 to 7 phase velocities for both the reinforced and the reinforced free medium are shown. Evidently, phase velocity for the reinforced medium is greater than that of the reinforced free medium. Figure 2.
Curve of c/β1 versus kH for νH=0.0 in the presence of reinforcement.
Figure 3.
Curve of c/β1 versus kH for νH=0.0 in the absence of reinforcement. Figure 4.
Curve of c/β1 versus kH for νH=2.0 in the presence of reinforcement. Figure 5.
Curve of c/β1 versus kH for νH=2.0 in the absence of reinforcement. Figure 6.
Curve of c/β1 versus kH for νH=5.0 in the presence of reinforcement. Figure 7.
Curve of c/β1 versus kH for νH=5.0 in the absence of reinforcement.

sec.title: 6. Conclusions
sec.p: In this paper the dispersion relation for SH waves in a non-homogeneous self-reinforced layer over a semi infinite self-reinforced medium with an irregularity has been obtained in the closed form. The effect of the size of irregularity, non-homogeneity parameter and reinforcement on the phase velocity of SH waves has been depicted and shown by means of graphs. It is observed that phase velocity decreases with increase in the size of irregularity and non-homogeneity of the layer increases the phase velocity. Graphs have been plotted for both reinforced and reinforced free cases; a comparative study of these graphs reveals that reinforcement supports the phase velocity. In the isotropic case, when irregularity and non-homogeneity are absent, the dispersion equation matches with the classical SH wave equation.
